key_points: Chief Justice John Roberts opts out of presiding over Donald Trump’s second impeachment trial.
Roberts believes the Constitution allows him a reprieve since Trump is no longer the sitting president.
Sen. Patrick Leahy, president pro tempore of the Senate, will preside over the trial instead.
Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer noted Roberts’ choice on MSNBC’s “The Rachel Maddow Show.”
The Constitution specifies the chief justice presides over trials of sitting presidents, leading to debate over its application to former presidents.
Roberts has declined to comment on his decision or responsibilities regarding the impeachment trial after Trump left office.
Leahy expressed readiness to assume the responsibilities of presiding officer.
During Trump's first trial, Roberts attempted to maintain Senate decorum and refused politically sensitive demands, like revealing the whistleblower's identity.
Roberts aims to maintain the Supreme Court’s image of neutrality despite political pressures.
Trump's impeachment for inciting the January 6 insurrection marks a unique case, as he is a former president.
spokespersons: Sen. Patrick Leahy (president pro tempore of the chamber)
